Award.AwardTitle: University of Texas at Arlington - Spain Collaborative Research on Hazard Mitigation of Civil Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description

The objectives of the three-year IRES project are to: (1) expose IRES students to international high quality focused research experience on hazard mitigation of civil infrastructure with foreign expert mentorship; (2) increase the awareness of the students on the importance of global professional engagement, global engineering networking and the world wide criticality of the research topic; and (3) recruit and train students in the program, especially from under-represented groups, attract and retain them in engineering programs, and motivate them for graduate studies. The research projects will be held at AIDICO, Technological Institute of Construction, Valencia, Spain. AIDICO provides R&D services to improve building materials/systems, energy efficiency, safety and disaster resistance. AIDICO has an ongoing collaboration with UT Arlington covering research, student/staff exchange and educational activities. Six civil engineering or civil engineering bound undergraduates per year will be recruited from two universities and several community colleges for the 6-week summer program (18 total). The common theme of the IRES site is Hazard Mitigation of Civil Infrastructure. Six novel IRES research projects (one for each student) that stem from ongoing AIDICO projects have been designed. The AIDICO projects have excellent correlation with the Disaster Mitigation Group at UTA, a multi-disciplinary effort of faculty members and public/private sectors. Significant collaboration among students, graduate students, faculty and mentors during and post summer, plus extensive dissemination activities are included. The proposed IRES project includes an effective assessment component that will gauge the impact of the project on the IRES students.

Non-Technical Description
The program will train students to solve hazard mitigation issues for civil infrastructure involving natural, man-made and accidental events. This is especially important with the increased worldwide occurrences of natural, man-made and accidental disasters in recent years, the deteriorating infrastructure with widespread failure and extensive human, economic and social effects. The project provides an excellent opportunity to integrate research and education. Students will be involved in hands on cutting-edge research under expert mentoring, field trips, presentations, workshops, intellectual and continuous collaboration, all well-designed to broaden the student's educational experience. The early academic research exposure is expected to eventually produce global scientists and engineers. The program is designed to inform students of and motivate them for engineering degrees and graduate education. The faculty members and foreign mentors have extensive expertise in the research topic. Excellent resources from various sources will be leveraged. The project will produce improved knowledge in critical hazard mitigation issues on the building construction area. A majority of the recruited students will be from under-represented groups from the partner universities and colleges. IRES/non-IRES faculty members from these groups will be role models and mentors on research and career choices. The project will nurture long-term partnerships with the students, faculty members and AIDICO collaborators through continuous academic year focus group meetings, faculty mentoring and virtual/social media contacts. Results will be disseminated broadly through journal publications, conference presentations, student workshop and chapter presentations, dedicated website/blog, and social media. The societal benefits are: the student's increased awareness of and ability to devise hazard mitigation efforts, increased interest in engineering education/careers, capacity to develop foreign collaborations, and finding original/imaginative and critically needed solutions for a global societal challenge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Research Experience for Students (IRES) project at UTA trained students to solve hazard mitigation issues for civil infrastructure involving natural, manmade and accidental events. This is especially important with the increased worldwide occurrences of natural, manmade and accidental disasters in recent years, the deteriorating infrastructure with widespread failure and extensive human, economic and social effects. The project provided an excellent opportunity to integrate research and education. Students were involved in hands on cutting-edge research under expert mentoring, field trips, presentations, workshops, intellectual and continuous collaboration, all well designed to broaden the student's educational experience. Addressing well designed and original research hypotheses for each project enabled students to find transformative solutions that had potential for immediate practical application. The early academic research exposure is expected to eventually produce global scientists and engineers. The program was designed to inform students of and motivate them for engineering degrees and graduate education. The faculty members and foreign mentors had extensive expertise in the research topic. Faculty members had additional experience in pre-engineering educational/research efforts, such as NSF REU and RET projects. Excellent resources from various sources were leveraged.

The IRES activities advanced discovery by engaging students in collaborative projects with international research leaders who were involved in cutting-edge research projects. The project produced improved knowledge in critical hazard mitigation issues on the building construction area. Students were recruited at universities and community colleges with significant enrollments from underrepresented groups. The students were benefitted from the high-quality mentorship and research opportunity at the well-known foreign locations. The project nurtured long-term partnerships with the students, faculty members and foreign collaborators through continuous academic year focus group meetings, faculty mentoring and virtual/social media contacts. Results were disseminated broadly through journal publications, conference presentations, student workshop and chapter presentations, dedicated website/blog, and social media. The societal benefits were: the student's increased awareness of and ability to devise hazard mitigation efforts, increased interest in engineering education/careers, capacity to develop foreign collaborations, and finding original/imaginative and critically needed solutions for a global societal challenge.

The IRES project had the following outcomes:

1. Exposure to International Research: Students in the IRES project actively participated in the summer research projects to be held at the AIDICO facility in Valencia, Spain, specifically designed for the IRES project. They effectively participated in research projects that were sub-sets of larger research projects underway at AIDICO, and then the Polytechnic University of Valencia. The students worked under the guidance of famed foreign experts who are involved in the larger projects. The unifying theme of the research projects is "Hazard Mitigation of Civil Infrastructure". They increased their knowledge about Hazard Mitigation. This means that even though the students were confident in their abilities to conduct research, the experience in the IRES program exposed them to many research related issues that they were not aware of previously.

2. Global Awareness: IRES participants demonstrated increased awareness of the global nature of today’s engineering profession through their involvement in the IRES project. They gained an understanding of the importance of professional networking at the international level through the foreign networking opportunity offered by the IRES project.

3. Recruitment and Retention: This IRES program aided in bolstering recruitment and retention in engineering degree programs of U.S. citizens and permanent residents, especially those from under-represented groups. The program enhanced the student’s potential to eventually pursue graduate degrees through exposure to high quality research, and information on graduate studies and mentoring. The project supported a total of 18 students in three cohorts; roughly 33% (6/18) were females and 72% (13/18) were from underrepresented minorities. Through the integration of engineering research and culturally relevant pedagogy into the curriculum and instruction of undergraduate students, the UT Arlington IRES project also had a direct impact on diverse student populations in today’s society.
